rev.comment: This does not seem OK since there is no indication the code will ever be oppened. Some references like the blog of Mark Shuttleworth or similar would be OK.
rev.diff:
Line 35: Line 35:
The first is that there is not yet a native client integration for the [[Kubuntu]] variant of the Ubuntu operating system (as of June 2010)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntuone-client/+bug/375145 |title=Launchpad bug #375145 - Ubuntu One should have a KDE client | accessdate=2010-06-12}}</ref>. Kubuntu integration is under development and has also received a grant from the Google Summer of Code 2010.
The first is that there is not yet a native client integration for the [[Kubuntu]] variant of the Ubuntu operating system (as of June 2010)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntuone-client/+bug/375145 |title=Launchpad bug #375145 - Ubuntu One should have a KDE client | accessdate=2010-06-12}}</ref>. Kubuntu integration is under development and has also received a grant from the Google Summer of Code 2010.
â
The second problem is the closed-source nature of the server side of Ubuntu One, though many{{Who|date=June 2010}} expect that Canonical will eventually open source the Ubuntu One Server, once it becomes sufficiently stable, as it happened with the [[Launchpad (website)|Launchpad]] open source hosting facility.
+
The second problem is the closed-source nature of the server side of Ubuntu One.
Further criticism concerns the choice of the patented mp3 format for the music of the Ubuntu One Music Store and the unclear revenue share that will be granted to the community. The Amarok development team has announced that they will not add support to the Ubuntu One Music Store to the Amarok media player for the moment, unlike what they have done with Magnatune media store, which funds the project with 10% of the revenue produced via the interface to the store built in Amarok.
Further criticism concerns the choice of the patented mp3 format for the music of the Ubuntu One Music Store and the unclear revenue share that will be granted to the community. The Amarok development team has announced that they will not add support to the Ubuntu One Music Store to the Amarok media player for the moment, unlike what they have done with Magnatune media store, which funds the project with 10% of the revenue produced via the interface to the store built in Amarok.
